Turn the oxygen off first and it won’t make that pop. Also you should get the cutting nozzle and have fun cutting stuff. It will only cut properly if the metal oxidizes. I took a class completely on oxy-acetylene and it was mind boggling the science behind it. Also make sure to suit up completely because if you move to fast or cut incorrectly it will shoot molten steel in places that you don’t want it to go.

So I don't know if my last post went through. But I asked a question. Is Silly Putty a Non-Newtonian Fluid? If a fluid is defined as a substance that takes the form of it's container, and a solid is defined as a rigid material such as a wooden block, then Silly Putty fits the definition of a fluid, a very viscous fluid. Silly Putty also happens to keeps it's form under high impact, thus allowing it to bounce off of hard surfaces. So since it maintains a certain level of rigidity during high impact moments such that a normal fluid would conform to the impacted surface itself, Silly Putty could be observed as a Non-Newtonian Fluid. This is my assumption.

For Heaven's sake TURN THE ACETYLENE DOWN! You're burning with far too much fuel, so you're not getting the right flame or anything like the temperature you should. The bright white flame is typical of acetylene in air or with far too little oxygen. You need to turn the acetylene regulator WAY down, then slowly increase the O2 until you get a translucent purple flame with a blue cone. That'll give you at least a thousand degrees more than you had there. Try it; you'll like it!
